description: From French vaisseau rasé, from raser (“to rase, to cut down ships”). See raze and rase (verbs).

entries.meaning: (nautical) An armed ship with its upper deck cut away, and thus reduced to the next inferior rate, such as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.

verbs.description: razee (third-person singular simple present razees, present participle razeeing, simple past and past participle razeed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To cut (a ship) down to a smaller number of decks, and thus to an inferior rate or class.
(transitive, figurative) To trim or abridge by cutting off parts.
examples: to razee a book, or an article
